Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY
Scenes.Description: MARTIN CONNELLY is waiting in his coat. Donna comes to him.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. Connelly?
Yes.
I'm Donna Moss, I'm Josh Lyman's assistant. He's tied up with Mr. McGarry for just a couple of more minutes, I hope you don't mind waiting.
No.
[walking through the bullpen] Does anybody know if it's gonna rain this afternoon? They're asking me.
The paper said mid-afternoon.
So we know it won't be that. Cal the Navy Yard for me, would you?
Yeah. Ed and Larry approach, laughing.
Donna.
Yeah.
Have you seen C.J.?
No. What's so funny?
Ed just got a fax... [laughing] I'm sorry. Ed just got a fax from a man named Byron Talmadge. He's the Associate Administrator for NASA's Office of Space Cadets....
Flight.
Office of Space Flight.
The OSF.
What's the fax say?
A huge Chinese satellite is gonna come crashing to Earth, and we don't know where, and we don't know when.
Seriously?
Yeah, it's right here in the fax.
I satellite is... crashing to Earth and NASA sent us a fax?
Yeah.
This is for real.
Yes.
[terrified] A satellite is gonna crush into the Earth? ED and LARRY Yes!
Why are you laughing?
We thought it was funny. [The two of them turn to leave.]
I'm an assistant. What am I supposed to do with this information?
The fax was for C.J., just give it to her when you see her.
Donna, they say it's not going to rain this afternoon.
Well, that's a relief. [walks off]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is sitting on his desk next to Josh and Toby.

Dialogues.Line: All right, hear me out on this, okay?
Yeah.
We want to see some polling.
Why?
'Cause we need to know what to do next.
We know what to do next.
No, we don't know which is the more insurmountable problem - the perception that... [stops abruptly as Margaret knocks and comes in with a note for Leo]
[returning the note] We'll call back. [Margaret leaves.]
[sighs] ... the perception that he's not physically up to the job or that he lied about it.
There's no way to gauge public opinion on this until the issue occurs. Public opinion is gonna be shaped by the reaction of the press.
All public opinion's shaped by the reaction of the press, but the fundamental foundation already exists in their current perception that the President...
Josh, how are you gonna take a poll without...?
We can do it.
Look...
Leo.
I don't' trust any of our people, and even if I did, what kind of questions could they ask that won't trip an alarm?
Josh trusts Joey Lucas.
From California?
Yes, she's flying in right now.
What did you tell her?
I told her we were commissioning a poll to explore attitudes towards subsurface agricultural products.
Subsurface agricultural... what the hell...?
Underground. We think Americans are eating more beats.
Beats?
Yeah.
All right.
Okay?
Yeah. Toby, you want to talk about when we tell Sam?
I wouldn't do it right now.
Why?
His head is in the SME speech for Chicago...
The thing...
Hang on. His head is in Chicago and that's where we need him. Would you want to write a speech with this other thing around your neck?
No.
The President wants him to know by the end of the day.
The end of the day, then.
Okay. Anything else?
No. Thanks.
Thank you.
Thank you. Toby and Josh exit to the HALLWAY. Toby waits for Josh to close the door, and they walk.
When does she get here?
Six o'clock.
We do this carefully.
No kidding.
You trust this person?
[beat] I gotta trust somebody, right?
Good, 'cause I don't trust anybody right now. [walks off]
Josh?
[walking to her] Yeah.
A fax was sent to the Press Office from the Office of Space Flight at NASA. A Chinese satellite called Zodiac has fallen off its orbit and will be falling to Earth at an unspecified time and place.
What are you telling me for?
What am I telling you for?
Yeah.
This giant thing is falling to Earth. They're watching it on radar. Isn't there something we do?
Like what?
Like sound the alarm?
Sound the alarm?
There is no alarm...
There's really not. Josh approaches Martin Connelly in the LOBBY.
Martin?
[stands up] Yes.
Sorry to keep you waiting.
Oh, that's okay.
Come on back.
Josh...
The fax is for the press office, give it to them.
The deputies are at breakfast, and I don't know where C.J. is.
Uh, Martin, you can have a seat in my office. [to Donna, quietly] C.J. is meeting with Babish. I'll be inside. Josh and Martin walk in JOSH'S OFFICE.
I apologize again.
No, that's all right. [sits, clutching his briefcase] I assume you know why I'm here.
[as his beeper goes off] I don't, actually.
Mack Sheridan was going to talk to you first.
[waves his beeper] I have a call to return to Mack.
I should wait until he talks to you first.
Why don't you talk to me now?
The case is running out of money.
Which case?
The US v...
You're kidding me!
No!
Martin, we spent 13 million the first year, 23 million the second... Where's the money going?
Outside counsel and staff, depositions, expert witnesses, processing database, research...
Yeah.

[raising his voice] We have 31 lawyers on a case against 5 tobacco companies, just one of which has 342. We won't count the 13 subsidiaries that have mounted their own defense. Tobacco has spent 380 million dollars to the government's 36, so when I come here asking you for money, it's not because the Justice Department blew its allowance on videogames! [beat] I should have let Mack talk to you first.
Aren't allowed to transfer funds...
Yeah, that's what we've been doing. We've been transferring money from Commerce and Health and Human Services to pay for the lawsuit. But then the House passed the HR-260 and now the Committees...
Yeah.
You understand?
Yeah, let me run it by Leo.
[gets up] This is a fight worth winning.
You don't have to convince me.
These people perpetrated a fraud against the public.
I'm sorry?
I said they perpetrated a fraud against the public.
[stares at Connelly] The... tobacco companies.
Yeah.
Well, I'm... gonna talk to Leo and I'll tell Mack you were here.
Thank you. He leaves, while Josh continues looking at the spot he just stood in.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OFFICE OF THE WHITE HOUSE COUNSEL - DAY
Scenes.Description: Oliver and C.J. are watching a videotape of C.J.'s press briefing.

Dialogues.Line: Let me just finish this. He was hemodynamically stable at a blood pressure of 140 over 80. Cholesterol level is 185, the QRS interval on the EKG is slightly long but otherwise good. The President is pronounced in excellent physical health. Oliver turns off the recording.
What was that? March of last year?
Yeah. How many times you've done that?
I'd have to go back and check.
Estimate.
If that was March of last year, then that was his fourth physical, then there were a couple of times during the campaign, and after the shooting...
Yeah.
And the time he rode his bicycle into a tree.
When he sprained his ankle.
Yeah.
[stands up and walks to pour himself more water] Tell me how it works.
What do you mean?
When the President has a physical.
The President's physician - right now it's Admiral Leonard Morrow - the President's physician calls me, gives me a short statement including vitals.
And then you make a statement to the Press?
Yeah.
[sits down with the glass of water] Do you also speak with the President before you make the statement?
Yes.
Why?
Because of doctor-patient confidentiality there's only so much you're gonna get from the doctors.
So what do you ask the President?
I say, is there anything I should know about your health that the doctors won't tell me.
I'm gonna ask you something.
What?
Do you say, 'is there anything I should know' or do you say 'is there anything I need to know?'
What does it matter?
Which do you say?
What does it matter?
'Is there anything I need to know' implies you only want to know enough to face reporters while maintaining deniability.
It's an expression.
Did you use it?
I really don't remember, I don't. I don't choose my words that carefully?
With the President?
You think I was speaking to the President in code?
No. I was just asking. Knocking on door.
Yeah!
[comes in] Excuse me, C.J., this is a note from Donna Moss, who wanted you to see it right away.
Thanks. The staffer leaves, she reads the note and shows it to Oliver.
The sky is falling down.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: A dozen aides are seated at the table listening as Sam paces around the table reading a draft of the SME speech.

Dialogues.Line: "The debate over a tax cut - whether to have one or not, how large it should be, how small it should be, what share should be received by whom - all of this, my friends, is the wrong debate at the wrong time over the wrong issue." Yes. We need to get back to fundamentals.
Where is that?
Where is what?
"We need to get back to fundamentals."
It's not in the speech. I'm saying it. We need to get back to fundamentals. There's a knock at the door. Sam glances over at the door, then turns back to the aides.
Excuse me. Think about fundamentals. Sam steps into the hall. JANE GENTRY and RICHARD WILL are waiting for him.
Ready for some good news?
Yeah.
Not out here. They walk around the corner toward SAM'S OFFICE.
This is gonna be a front-page story tomorrow.
There's a front-page story tomorrow I don't know about yet?
Well, you're gonna know about it in two hours.
But I'm gonna know about it now, right? Sam closes the door of his office. They all remain standing.
The CBO's gonna issue a new estimate of the surplus.
They're projecting it down?
Yeah.
We don't have as much money as we thought?
No.
That's great news.
Yeah.
It's not great news that we have less money. I'm saying...
Yeah.
'Cause the floor fight's gonna be easier.
Yeah.
How much less money?
Well, when they project eight years out, it's 200 billion less. Nine years out, it's 400 billion less.
That is great.
Yeah.
It's not great that we have less...
Sam, we get why it's great.
I can't even tell you how much this helps. I'm drafting the SME speech for Chicago and I could really...
That's why we're telling you. There's a line that ATJ and the Progressive Caucus want in the Chicago speech.
[hands sheet of paper to Sam] I got it here.

[reading] "We want a real tax cut for working families to help them pay for higher education and housing, while our opponents want to help the rich pay for bigger swimming pools and faster private jets. [pause] No, I don't think so.
They want it in.
No, no, no.
Why not?
Well, for one thing, it's very bad writing.
Summer homes and sports cars.
The poetry's not my problem.
They want it in Chicago.
Well, tell them to do their own speech. This one's for the President.
You wanna tell them that?
No.
Okay.
We have less money?
Isn't that great?
Yes, it is. Thanks. Jane and Richard leave. Sam watches them go.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OFFICE OF THE WHITE HOUSE COUNSEL - DAY
Scenes.Description: A glass pitcher and drinking glasses rest in the center of the table between Oliver and C.J. Her arms are crossed in a defensive posture.

Dialogues.Line: C.J., are you aware that a year ago January the President had an attack?
I am now.
You were there when he collapsed.
I was outside the room.
But you went into the room when he was unconscious.
Yes.
What made you go into the room?
The sound of a Stueben glass pitcher crashing to the floor.
What did you think had happened?
I didn't know.
Well, what did you think? C.J.'s tone becomes very sarcastic.
Well, at first glance, I thought he might have a virus contracted from a rare African tsetse fly, possibly tropical sprue. I'm not an expert, but I did meet a man once in India.
Yeah.
It could be anything with these Presidents. James Polk had diverticulitis.
Yeah.
Couldn't digest nuts. I'll tell you what else. One in forty American men wear women's clothing, and we've had well over forty Presidents.
Yeah.
I'm just sayin', one of these guys was dancing around the Oval Office in a prom dress. Now let's get to the bottom of that.
C.J.?
Yeah?
In my entire life I've never found anything charming.
[after long pause] Really?
You announced to the press it was the flu.
Yes.
Who told you to say it was the flu?
I wasn't told to say it was the flu. I was told it was the flu
Who told...?
[yelling] I'm not getting into that! I'm not getting into who said what. We can do that at the next of what I'm sure will be many sessions.
Okay. [pause] Do you know what time it is? C.J. pauses and glances to her right, presumably at a clock on the wall.
It's five past noon.
I'd like you to get out of the habit of doing that.
Doing what?
Answering more than was asked... Do you know what time it is? C.J. stares at him silently for several moments.
[annoyed] Yes.
We'll take a break and meet again later today. C.J. wearily gets up to leave.

Dialogues.Character: CUT TO INT. THE WHITE HOUSE MESS
Dialogues.Line: DAY Sam walks into the Mess and spots Toby sitting alone at a table drinking coffee and reading a folded up section of a newspaper.
Hey.
[holds up newspaper] You see this?
That was nice.
We got good reviews on the commencement speech.
Yeah.
From Maynard Wachtel, of all places. Toby tosses the newspaper on the table, stands up, and walks over to the coffee counter.
You got a second?
He calls you and me the Batman and Robin of speech-writing.
Well, I don't think he does...
He doesn't, but he should, 'cause that's what we are.
Okay. Toby grabs a pastry from the counter as he refills his coffee mug. His speech is a bit slurred as he chews.
We're Batman and Robin!
Which one's which?
Look at me, Sam. Am I Robin?
I'm not Robin.
Yes, you are.
Okay, well, let's move off this.
You bet, little friend. They walk through the Mess toward the STAIRS.
Listen, we're really not Batman and Robin.
No, we'll keep those identities secret. I'm Bruce Wayne, and you're my ward...
Toby...
...Dick something.
Jane Gentry and Richard Will came to see me with some news. The CBO's projection...
Really?
Yes. Has us 200 billion lower eight years out.
That's fantastic news.
Yes.
When is this real?
This afternoon.
The projections are lower?
Measurably lower.
I'm so happy I could spit.
This is really the first administration in history to favor slower economic growth.
I favor it when it gives us a bat and ball on tax cuts.
Yeah.
We offer 'em a deal. We lower the bottom rate from fifteen to ten percent, but we stand our ground on no tax cut in the top bracket, and you know why? They walk in the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
'Cause it turns out we might not be able to afford it.
Isn't it great?
Yeah, it's Christmas in Paris, but there's a line ATJ and the Progressive Caucus want me to put in the draft for Chicago.
What? They end up in TOBY'S OFFICE.
That we want to do great things, but our opponents want bigger swimming pools and faster private jets.
Their private jets are too slow?
Toby...
Change the writing.
It's not the writing.
I know. [sigh] Listen...
Yeah? Toby walks toward the door, but doesn't say anything for several moments.
Nothing.
Okay.
Don't worry about it.
So...
I have to go to a meeting. You should talk to somebody at ATJ or the Caucus.
Okay, I'm gonna do that then.
Yeah.
Okay. They walk in opposite directions down that hall.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Charlie is sitting at his desk working on the computer. Donna walks in with a smile on her face.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, Donna.
Hey, Charlie.
Is there anything you need?
Nope. Just came in to say hi.
How you doing? Charlie stands up to get something from the storage closet.

Good. [long pause] So, NASA's OSF tells us that the 30th Space Wing at Vandenberg Air Force Base believes that a Chinese satellite has fallen out of its orbital... flight plan. The last detection the 30th had placed it in what they call a "degrading orbital path" and it's now dropped off their radar, suggesting it's begun a rapid fall towards the Earth's atmosphere.
[walks back behind his desk] Cool.
No, it's not! What's the matter with you people?
What'd I do?
A thing the size of a garbage truck is gonna be in a two-thousand-mile-an-hour free fall and no one knows where it's gonna hit!
I'm rooting for Zurich.
Charlie...
I've had it up to here with the Swiss.
You don't...
Hang on... [checks his pager] Excuse me. Charlie leaves. Donna sighs and walks back toward her office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WHITE HOUSE PORTICO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Several female aides and a Secret Service agents are standing by the passenger door of a black limousine. The agent opens the door. Abbey is sitting inside with dark glasses on. She quickly steps out of the car.

Dialogues.Line: Good afternoon.
Welcome back, Mrs. Bartlet.
Thank you. Abbey removes her glasses and walks briskly through the HALLWAY. She's all business. The aides follow her. Other aides join the pedeconference as Abbey heads toward the Oval Office.
A couple of reminders. You're at the Board of the Children's Cancer Fund at the Sheraton. That's at 300.
Before that I wanna be...
Yeah, you're gonna read at the Head Start program in SouthEast.
Welcome back, Mrs. Bartlet.
That's a snappy suit, Bobby.
How did it go yesterday?
I had a medevac helicopter named after me.
Yeah?
An AS335 F1 Twinstar named Abigail. I got to break a bottle of cider over its nose. [hands her glasses and briefcase to the aide]
Charlie.
Welcome back, ma'am.
Thank you. Where's the President?
He's waiting for you inside.
Thank you. Abbey opens the door to THE OVAL OFFICE and closes it behind her. Bartlet is standing by his desk reading. He turns at the sound of the door and walks toward her.
Hey.
Hi.
Welcome back. They are facing each other, about a foot apart.
How come I just found out about this?
How was the flight?
Jed... How come I just found out about this?
When Leo talked to you on the plane, he thought you already knew. Abbey starts pacing around the room and raises her voice slightly.
You think I'm saying this is Leo's fault? I'm asking how come you didn't tell me last week?

And I'm saying, we still do this. We're husband and wife and parents, and before we launch into palace intrigue, we do, "Welcome back. How was the flight?" Abbey stops pacing and nods, but only with her eyes.
What happened?
One of the forms Zoey had to fill out for Georgetown asked for a family medical history.
Yes.
Did Leo tell you the rest?
[testily] Not after he realized that you hadn't told me already! Which is a subject, I assure you, we will be turning to in a moment.
Zoey wasn't eighteen yet when she started. A parent had to sign the form.
Did you sign it?
No, you did, Hot Pants.
I signed it?
It's gonna be okay.
[exasperated] Why didn't you tell me this on the phone?
Look...
[gritting her teeth, really angry] We talk on the phone three times a day!

[shouting] Cause I didn't! 'Cause that's... [lowers his voice slightly] 'Cause I didn't! They stare at each other for several long moments. They both look exhausted, miserable, and a bit scared. Bartlet sighs repeatedly, looks away from her, and shifts from side to side several times. Abbey watches him, sighs heavily, and slowly walks over to a chair. Wearily, she sits down. She stares straight ahead, not looking at him. She has a sad, resigned look on her face.
I talked to Zoey this morning. She's gonna ace her finals.
She told me.
I hate Ellie's boyfriend. Abbey looks up at him, but he's not looking at her.
She told me. Bartlet slowly and uneasily meets her gaze.>
I need you to speak to the White House Counsel, Abbey.
[quietly] I know. They stare at each other silently.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. SHOT OF WHITE HOUSE AND WASHINGTON MONUMENT - DAY

Dialogues.Line: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE, MARGARET'S DESK - DAY Josh is seated beside Margaret's desk. Leo walks in and grabs his messages off the desk.
Hey.
The First Lady's back?
Yeah. They walk silently into LEO'S OFFICE. Leo closes the door.
I was talking to her on the phone and I mentioned Zoey's application without realizing the President hadn't told her yet.
Why hadn't the President told her yet?
What do you want from me?
Thirty million dollars.
No.
Martin Connelly, who's an Assistant Attorney General in the Civil Division, says they're out of money.
On the suit?
Yeah.
[exasperated] They're always out of money.
We don't give 'em enough.
We passed a law last summer that says they can transfer funds from Commerce, from Health and Human Services. They can take it from Veteran's Affairs up to what? I think twelve million dollars.

Yeah, but the problem is the law says that those transfers are subject to approval by various House committees, each of which has a chairman elected with the eight million dollars Tobacco spent in the last election. And even if the transfers were approved, it wouldn't matter, 'cause twelve million isn't gonna get it done.
Neither is thirty million.
Then let's give 'em more.
No.
Why?
'Cause we're gonna lose.
So you give 'em enough to win.
We'd have to liquidate the Grand Tetons.
They're saying thirty million and I think it's a steal at twice the price. Leo is reading his phone messages and only half listening to Josh at this point.
Staff it out to some people and report to me on it in what...?
Two, three days?
Good.
I'm going out to the airport. Josh stands up and walks toward the door.
[looks up from his messages] All right... Do a job.
[turns to look at Leo] Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam walks into the room. Several members of the Progressive Caucus - including Henry, Helen, Bruce and Lewis - are standing around the table waiting for him.

Dialogues.Line: Hi.
Hey, Sam.
Henry, Helen. Hey, Bruce.
How you doing, Sam? Everyone except Sam and Henry sit.
Lewis. We just have a few minutes, right?
There's a caucus.
Well, you've already heard the good news. The CBO, when they project eight years out, has the budget surplus coming in 200 billion dollars lower than we thought.
That's great.

Yeah, okay, there's something wrong with all of us, but that's for a different time. [finally takes a seat] What I wanted to mention was Jane Gentry and Richard Will say you guys want a line in the Chicago draft.
"Jet planes and swimming pools."
Yeah, that "our opponents want to help the rich pay for bigger swimming pools and faster private jets."
Yeah, hit 'em hard.
Well, we are hitting them hard, but I'm not gonna use the line.
Why not?
First of all, it's bad writing.
What's wrong with it? [sits]
It sounds like it was written by a high school girl.
Is there something wrong with the way a woman writes?
There usually is when she's in high school.
Sam!
It's not the writing. Come on, Henry! "Faster private jets and swimming pools?"
We can take out the heavy bats now.
And do what with them?
The line works.
So does "How about 'em Cowboys?" when you're playing a club in Dallas, but the line isn't gonna change the mind of anyone who doesn't already agree with us.
Sam, are you in favor of tax cuts for the wealthy?

I am not. I am in favor of tax cuts for those for whom it will do the most good - and that's a tough enough battle - and it looks like, all of a sudden, we've got a fair fight. But I'm not talking about policy. I'm talking about rhetoric, and the men you work for need to dial it down to five. Several of the Caucus members exchange annoyed glances.

Henry, last fall, every time your boss got on the stump and said, "It's time for the rich to pay their fair share," I hid under a couch and changed my name. I left Gage Whitney making $400,000 a year, which means I paid twenty-seven times the national average in income tax. I paid my fair share, and the fair share of twenty-six other people. And I'm happy to 'cause that's the only way it's gonna work, and it's in my best interest that everybody be able to go to schools and drive on roads, but I don't get twenty-seven votes on Election Day. The fire department doesn't come to my house twenty-seven times faster and the water doesn't come out of my faucet twenty-seven times hotter. The top one percent of wage earners in this country pay for twenty-two percent of this country. Let's not call them names while they're doing it, is all I'm saying.
You're not using the line?
No.
Or anything like it?
No. And I hope you'll make it clear to your people that this has nothing to do with diluting our position or cozying up to Republicans.
[sarcastically] No, why would they think that?
We've got a caucus. The Caucus members get up and start to leave. Sam remains seated.

[over his shoulder] I know plenty of women who can write, Helen. I know women who can blow the walls of brick buildings. This sounds like a girl. Helen doesn't respond, just stares at him for a moment, and leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL AIRPORT TERMINAL - DAY

Dialogues.Line: ...Airlines Flight 1106, arriving from Los Angeles, is now in Gate Six... Joey Lucas and a new interpreter, DALE BRACKET, walk through the terminal amidst waves of people. Josh spots them and catches Dale's attention.>
Joey! Dale taps Joey on the shoulder and points at Josh, who is walking quickly toward them.
Joey... How you doing?
Hey!
[to Dale] I'm Josh Lyman.
Dale Bracket. [They shake hands.]
What happened to Kenny?
He's on vacation.
[to Dale] So you're the substitute interpreter?
Yeah.
[pleased] You came here to pick me up at the airport?

Not exactly. Uh, Dale, I'm gonna ask you to wait over her, okay?... Uh, Joey, you're gonna read my lips, and if I can't understand what you're saying, you'll write it down, all right? Joey nods, looking perplexed but amenable.
Okay.
[to Dale] Excuse us. Josh and Joey walk away from Dale.
Dale? Josh looks over his shoulder at Dale.
Yes.
Pretty good-looking for an interpreter, wouldn't you say?
He's good-looking for anybody.
Dale Bracket?
Yes.
[sarcastically] He's not a television detective?
We can't talk about this in the car?
I'm sorry?
[a bit louder] We can't talk about this in the car?
You're not getting in the car.
Why?

'Cause you're getting back on a plane in an hour and ten minutes. They sit down at a table in the middle of a bar that is along the side of the terminal. Joey, increasingly confused, drops her bags next to her chair, Josh sighs heavily.
All right, if we sit like this, can Dale Bracket, PI, read my lips?
[slightly annoyed] No.
Okay... You're not talking to me about an agriculture poll.
No kidding.
You guessed that?
You think we're eating more beets?
Well, we are, but... that's not important.
What's important?
Hi, what can I get for you? Joey grabs a napkin and writes on it while Josh orders.
Uh, cranberry juice and club soda...and, um, I'll have a large glass of ice water. Joey slides the napkin across the table to Josh. She's written, "What's important?"
I told Leo McGarry that we could trust you, and Toby backed me up.
[nodding] What's important?

[swallows apprehensively] Eight years ago, the President was diagnosed with an illness that was never disclosed. Joey absorbs this information pretty calmly. She writes on the napkin again and Josh picks it up. She's written, "Is it serious?"
[softly] Yes.
What is it? Josh stares at her as he signs the letters "M" and "S."
Cranberry and club... and a large glass of ice water. Joey looks sad and concerned, but doesn't say anything as the waitress sets their drinks on the table.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE COUNSEL'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: There's a knock on the door and it opens. Oliver's aide steps into the room.>

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me... The First Lady.
Thank you. Abbey nonchalantly but resolutely strides into the office.
Oliver.
Good afternoon, Mrs. Bartlet. [They shake hands.]
How are you?
I'm fine, thank you.
[paces nervously] You know, I haven't been in this office since you moved in. It looks great.
Thank you. Oliver paces a bit, then stops and turns to face her. Abbey keeps pacing.
I haven't come in here because it seems that every time I do, there's a new White House Counsel. I think Leo keeps them in the basement, like those two ladies in Arsenic and Old Lace.
Yeah?
Anyway, the President is very glad you're here, particularly in this time of nonsense.
Ma'am, would you mind if I asked you a few questions?

[allows just a bit of a nervous smile to appear] I'm not as experienced in this as the senior staff... I've read a book about Daniel Webster. I've read a book about Benjamin Disraeli. It seems the little experience I do have is with dead lawyers.
Just out of curiosity, ma'am, how'd they die?
If you're under the impression that you're the fifth White House Counsel instead of the first White House Counsel because of me, you're mistaken, Oliver.
I wasn't under that impression, but I think we should stick to the matter, if it's all right with you.
[sighs] You want to ask me some questions?
Yes, ma'am.
About Zoey's health form.
Yep.
[shrugs slightly] It was a form. It asked for, among other things, the family's medical history. It was left blank. It was a form - it was one of many forms. I signed it without reading it.
Was anyone else in the room when you signed it?
Oh, it was over a year ago. I really don't remember.
Was the President in the room?
I really don't remember.
You understand that when I ask the President that question, he's gonna tell the truth?
[testily] And I imagine the President will also resent your implication that I didn't just do the same.
So the President wasn't in the room when you signed it?
[exasperated, shaking her head] I don't remember; he doesn't remember.
Mrs. Bartlet...
Oliver, you have kids, there are forms. School trips and soccer and band uniforms and report cards and notes to get out of gym. You've signed those forms for your kids.
Their mother usually signs them.
And so do I. And, by the way, when you're the daughter of the Governor of New Hampshire and the President of the United States, there's a lot more forms on top of that.
I understand.
[a bit sarcastically] Do you?
Yes. But a lawyer half my size, while cross-examining you during deposition, will say the following, he will say "Mrs. Bartlet, do you have an M.D. from Harvard?"
Yes.
"Are you board-certified in Internal Medicine?"
Yes.
"Are you board-certified in Thoracic Surgery?"
Yes.
"Are you an Adjunct Professor of Thoracic Surgery at Harvard Medical School?"
Yes.
"Are you on the staff of Boston Mercy Hospital and Columbia Presbyterian?"
Yes.
"Have you been practicing medicine for twenty-six years?"
[annoyed] Yes.
"Are you not able to recognize a standard medical history form when it is put in front of your face?"
I didn't read it! I didn't think it was important!
What else have you signed without thinking it was important? Prescriptions?
No!
Patient instructions?
No!
Oh, so just this?
Oliver, I am not an expert in the diseases of the central nervous system, but I can tell you that MS is not hereditary. The President's condition has absolutely no relevance to Zoey's health status.
Well, now you're changing your story, Mrs. Bartlet.
No, I'm not.
Did you sign it because you were absent-minded or did you sign it because you knew best?
I signed it 'cause...I just signed it...It was a form...And I think making a big thing out of it is what makes it into a big thing!
Really?
And I'm not a hundred percent sure that that's not what you're going for.
Why would I want to make it a big thing?
Because defending the President in primetime looks good on a resume.

Well, I've got a pretty good-looking resume already, Mrs. Bartlet. And it's not a big thing because I say so, ma'am; it's a big thing. You're gonna get all the questions I just asked you, and quite a few more. And then they're gonna ask the President if he was in the room when you signed it. And that's when he's gonna give everyone's favorite answer from a President who has just announced that he has MS: "I don't remember." Oliver sighs, walks to his desk chair and sits down. Abbey remains standing with her back turned to him. She looks a bit shaken. Neither of them say anything for several moments.
When are you gonna go public?
[faintly] Probably in a week. They're still strategizing.
Probably a live interview on the networks?
Yeah. [turns to look at him]
Jim Lehrer, Tim Russert, Barbara Walters... you... somebody... the President sitting in a den.
Yeah.
Followed by a live conference.
They're working on the strategy.
[imitating what the President might say] "I regret that I concealed my condition from the public. I regret the appearance that I tried to deceive the voters in order to win an election."
Yes.

And if we don't make it a big thing, they won't make it a big thing? [pause] Mrs. Bartlet, I'm not sure you have an appropriate appreciation of the size of what happens next. Abbey stares at Oliver. She looks completely shell-shocked, but does not respond.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. NATIONAL AIRPORT CONCOURSE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Joey and Josh are still talking.

Dialogues.Line: When are you going public?
Probably in about a week.
A week? How?

We're deciding. Probably a live interview, followed by a press conference. So we need to know what we're talking about. Joey, we need you to put a poll in the field. You got to come up with a model that gets us the answers we need without asking the questions we can't ask. You gotta come up with the model by yourself, you got to break down the results by yourself. Not even the callers can understand the questions they're asking. And you got to do it all in 96 hours. Is what I'm describing possible?
[nods] We make it a Governor.
A Governor?
Of an industrial state.
I don't... Joey writes on the napkin.
The Governor of an industrial state.
Michigan.
And you give him a degenerative illness. Joey nods.
Joey, you understand that before this is over we're probably all going to be spending some time in front of a grand jury. Joey nods.
You can do this?
No problem.
Los Angeles passengers pre-boarding for flight 1217...
That's your flight.
Josh?
Yeah.
How is the President?
[leaning away] He's fine. Joey touches Josh's chin and tilts his head up.
He's fine. I'll tell him you asked.
96 hours?
Yeah.
I have to go to work now. Joey gets up and exits. Josh takes the napkin and carefully crumples it in his drink.
The Chinese Embassy won't even admit it's their satellite.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: We know it's their satellite. We've been looking at it for seven years. It's like looking through a telescope and knowing Mars is Mars.
Donna, please tell me you didn't call the Chinese Embassy. They start a walk and talk.
I didn't call the Embassy -- "people" called the Embassy. It's not like this isn't cause for concern.
That's right.
That's right. The Chinese news networks don't report it 'cause they won't admit it's happening.
Why do you suppose the American news networks aren't reporting it?
That's a fascinating question to me.
To all of us.
We didn't know what kind of satellite it is.
Could be anything.
Communications.
That's right.
Weather.
Yep.
Could be a spy satellite.
Could have plutonium.
That's right. Charlie stops. Donna walks through double doors, stops, realizes what Charlie just said, and comes back.
Plutonium?
Yeah.
Plutonium.
Well, nuclear reactors on a satellite aren't that common, but you never know.
No, I suppose you don't. Donna goes back through the doors, and walks by Abbey for another walk and talk.
Hey, Donna.
Good evening, ma'am. Welcome back.
Thank you.
How was the trip?
Well, I got a MedEvac helicopter named after me. [as she passes staffers] Hello. [back to Donna] How are you?
I'm fine, but there's a giant object hurtling its way towards us at devastating velocity.
Tell me about it. Donna peels off, and Abbey walks into C.J.'S OFFICE.
[knocks] C.J.?
Good evening, ma'am.
Can I talk to you for a second?
Sure. Abbey closes the door, sighs, and sits down on the couch.
How was your day?
Well, I got pretty well bitch-slapped by the White House Counsel, ma'am, how about you?
[long pause] I wanted to be here when you were told. [beat] I didn't know they were going to tell you last night.

[sighs] You know, Leo called me into the Oval Office... It was about 11, and I was standing with Toby when Leo called me in and Toby said, uh, "I'll be right here in my office when you're done." [beat] I didn't know what he meant or why he said it.
Yeah.

Babish said there's a difference between asking the President, "Is there anything else I *should* know," and, "Is there anything else I *need* to know?" He seemed to think "need to know" implies I know something already, but I don't want it confirmed in order to maintain... deniability.
Well, he's a lawyer, C.J. He's vetting. It's his job.
I told him I couldn't remember which one I say.
There were a lot of things I couldn't remember.

Abey... [sits on couch] During the campaign, we were in Manhattan, Kansas, at a Sheraton, or a Marriott, I can't remember, but we were in Manhattan, Kansas... And I came to your suite early to tell you we'd be doing Nightline that night and we had to get to an ABC affiliate. And I think by then the two of you were so used to people walking in and out of your room that you didn't hear me open the door. And I was almost sure I saw you giving the President an injection of something.
It was Betaseron. It reduces the frequency of the attacks.
When the President has his physical, and I do the release, I only ever ask, "Is there anything else I need to know?"

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is inside. A knock on the door.

Dialogues.Line: Come on in. Josh enters, and closes the door behind him.
She's in.
What's she going to do?
"If the Governor of a major industrial state had a degenerative illness which he hadn't disclosed during the election but which has yet to impair his job performance, would you still support him?"
Which one?
Michigan.
Well... then we'll wait.
Yeah. [pause] Listen, about this Justice appropriation...
You gonna do a report?
Yeah.
Then, can I *read* the report before you ask me to green light another multi-million dollar battle that'll have no support in Congress?

Yeah. [pause] I just brought it up because this Assistant A.G., Martin Connelly, when he left my office this morning he turned and said, "They perpetrated a fraud against the public." And the look on his face when he said it... They want to get these people.
We're not big tobacco.
Yeah.
He's expecting me.
Leo crosses to the door to THE OVAL OFFICE. Bartlet inside, at his desk.
Good evening, Mr. President.
Leo, how could you tell Abbey about the health form before I did?
I didn't know you hadn't told her.
My wife and I are fighting battles on several fronts at the moment, including one with each other; can you and I be men? Can we have a bond?
We're putting a poll in the field.
How?
We're using a woman Josh and Toby trust named Joey Lucas.
I met Joey Lucas.
She's basically giving MS to the Governor of Michigan.
How's he gonna feel about that?
Don't worry about it.
This is a bad idea.
We've got to do it.
I'm coming clean, I'm doing it voluntarily. Anyone finds out, it's going to look like I did it because a poll told me to.
Then it'd be a good idea if nobody found out.
All right. [pause] Why don't you get Sam? Leo exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: So...
Yeah.
I think I may have offended...
Oh, God.
Yeah.
Who?
Well, I met with some of the staffers for Americans for Tax Justice and The Progressive Caucus.
And you think you may have offended them?
Yeah. [beat] And girls, possibly.
Were you right?
Yeah. Toby, it's class...
That's all you need to tell me. I trust you.
[enters] Sam?
Yeah.
Come see the President and me a minute, would you?
Yeah.
Sam?
Yeah?
I'll be here in the office when you're done.
Yeah, OK. Sam and Leo exit.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WASHINGTON D.C. - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is walking, and Josh catches up to her for a walk and talk.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.!
Hey.
You walking?
Yeah.
I met with Joey Lucas today.
I heard.
So now the President's got Leo worried it's going to look like we announced it because we took a poll. [beat] What do you think? C.J. starts to laugh, then completely loses it.
What?
The President and Leo are worried about that?
Yeah. What?

You guys are like Butch and Sundance peering over the edge of a cliff to the boulder-filled rapids 300 feet below, thinking you better not jump 'cause there's a chance you might drown. The President has this disease and has been lying about it, and you guys are worried that the polling might make us look bad? It's the fall that's gonna kill ya!
"Us."
What?
You said, "It's the fall that's gonna kill you." You meant, "us." C.J. turns away.
Where're you going, C.J.?
I'm going home.
No, I meant...
I know what you meant. I want to sleep for a while. I'm going home. Josh follows after her.
You know, uh, Donna got a hold of this fax that was sent to the press office from the O.S.F. at NASA.
What, something falling out of the sky?
Yeah.
We get that fax once a week.
Yeah, but Donna doesn't know that. She thinks it's an emergency.
And you didn't want to tell her?

No, 'cause the other way you get a day's worth of entertainment without leaving the office. She doesn't know that these things fall out of the sky all the time... once every ten days, as a matter of fact. Since the first year we started putting man-made objects in space, 17,000 have come back and remarkably, not one person has been hit. [beat] So I suppose there's an argument to be made that we're due.
Yeah. You picked me right up there, Josh. C.J. crosses the street.
See you tomorrow! We PAN UP to the "Pennsylvania Ave 1600 Block" street sign and --
